data.title: Elisa Izquierdo
data.meta_description: News about Elisa Izquierdo, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
Westchester

A Tragedy's Aftermath

The deaths last month of two toddlers, scalded in their tub in Yonkers while adults slept nearby, have cast the county's Department of Social Services in an unforgiving light. The boys' mother and the father of the younger child face criminal charges, and a caseworker was fired after investigators discovered that she had skipped meetings with the family in the months before the boys died. Officials have quickly placed blame in the most obvious places. But as the fuller story comes out -- all too slowly -- there is growing frustration among those who have seen this happen before and are furious that it has happened again.

2 Deaths Narrow Focus on Child Welfare Agency's Changes and Limits

News analysis contends that 1995 beating death of Elisa Izquierdo and this month's murder of Sylena Herrnkind has focused on New York City's Child Welfare Agency and progress it has made under Nicholas Scoppetta and improvements that are still needed to insure safety of children under their supervision (M)

By Nina Bernstein

Pattern Cited in Missed Signs of Child Abuse

Number of abused or neglected children reported to New York City's Children's Services Administration who subsequently died has risen in over three years since death of Elisa Izquierdo, 6, spurred agency overhaul; Children's Rights Inc holds cases show continuing pattern of caseworker and agency errors; city and state officials, while admitting city's child welfare system remains faulty, call Comr Nicholas Scoppetta's reforms most concerted effort in years to improve entrenched system (M)

By Nina Bernstein

Delay in Case Of Siblings Of Slain Child Stirs Debate

New York City Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani blames courts for New York City's failure to find permanent homes for siblings of Elisa Izquierdo, saying that child welfare officials and city lawyers had moved 'as fast as the law allows' to get 5 children adopted; advocates for foster children assail city's handling of case, saying that it reflects child welfare agency's routine disregard for thousands of children who languish for years in foster care (M)

By Rachel L. Swarns

Court Strikes Limits on City Workers' Speech to the News Media

US appeals court rules that regulations prohibiting workers at Human Resources Administration and Children's Services Administration from talking with reporters without their agency's permission are unconstitutional; case stems from lawsuit filed on behalf of Rosalie Harman, child welfare worker who was suspended after she discussed her agency on ABC news program in 1995 following death of Elisa Izquierdo (M)

By Benjamin Weiser

Panel Faults Caseworkers In Child Abuse

Report by judicially appointed panel of specialists concludes that one year after major overhaul of New York City's child welfare system, child abuse investigators continue to endanger lives of thousands of children with same missteps and sloppy casework that led to death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo; finds no improvement in quality of investigations of Administration for Children's Services, agency formed by Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani after series of errors led to beating death of Izquierdo in Nov 1995 (M)

By Rachel L. Swarns

2 Abuse Cases Put Spotlight On Scoppetta

Latest horrific child abuse cases in New York put spotlight on Nicholas Scoppetta and system he is supposed to reform; caseworkers dismissed six reports to state hotline about abuse of Cassandra White, who was burned on radiator by her mother; family of five-year-old Daytwon Bennett was visited 13 times by caseworker who noticed nothing wrong as child was slowly starved to death; Administration for Children's Services continues to suffer from negligent employees and sloppy investigations year after Mayor Rudolph Giuliani revamped system and appointed Scoppetta; Scoppetta, who actually dismissed one caseworker after death of Elisa Izquierdo, has hired 432 new workers, reduced caseloads and uupdated communications, but his zeal has not trickled down; abuse cases increased 36 percent, to 17,596, in 1996 (M)

By Rachel L. Swarns

Child-Abuse Panel Urges Looser Secrecy Laws

New York State Gov George Pataki's Commission on Child Abuse, one year after death of Elisa Izquierdo at hands of her mother led to loosening of secrecy laws in child abuse cases, recommends easing those laws even further to aid investigators and prosecutors; panel also recommends several other changes in state's child welfare system, including making endangering welfare of child a felony instead of misdemeanor in many cases and making it easier to remove children from abusive households (M)

By Randy Kennedy

Metro Matters

Elisa's Death: A Year Later, Hints of Hope

Joyce Purnick Metro Matters column on year anniversary of murder of Elisa Izquierdo by her mother Awilda Lopez in one of worst case of child abuse that New York City authorities have ever seen; says that Eliza's death tramatized New Yorkers and led to significant changes in child welfare agency's handling of child abuse cases (M)

By Joyce Purnick
